questions.neutral: Night's only just started, hasn't it?

hobby.message: Political literature still your guilty pleasure?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Long week. Needed a break.
I fly drones as a hobby—just for myself.
Sometimes the city makes it harder to find clear airspace.
Lately, those cracks are everywhere.
Yeah, night’s early.
I spend off-hours flying FPV drones.
Not the racing kind—mostly abandoned areas, for the view.
Security’s tighter since the blackout. Makes flying trickier.
Some people don’t like eyes in the sky right now.
Still early, right.
I get out to old industrial zones, fly freestyle FPV drones.
It helps clear my head better than anything else.
After the mural showed up, Directorate’s been all over those spots.
Signal interference is worse—can’t trust my usual frequencies.
Makes flying more interesting, though.
Night’s young, yeah. Sometimes it doesn’t really end...
I go out after work, freestyle drone flying—industrial yards, rooftops, canals.
You find freedom in tight spaces—threading broken cranes, dodging patrols.
Blackout made everyone nervous. Last flight, I picked up weird encrypted chatter.
Saw people covering cameras, setting up mesh repeaters near the mural area.
Strange to feel exposed from the air, not just on the ground.
Still, it’s a rush.
Feels like the city’s never really sleeping lately.
I’m out most nights, flying FPV drones through old zones.
Started years ago—helps me focus. Sometimes, it’s easier than being around people.
Last time out, picked up encrypted traffic while above the old mural wall.
Saw organized groups, covering sensors, painting over surveillance.
Signals are messier now. More jamming, more hidden networks, less trust everywhere.
I used to fly for fun, now it’s half survival exercise.
Funny how the blackout uncovered the mural and changed everything—even our blind spots.
hobby_answer: Analog mostly. Less traceable, if you know what I mean.
Harder to get clear signal lately.
Too much interference since the blackout. Nothing stable out there.
Lot of patrols after the mural. Not worth the risk sometimes.
Hobby’s changed. Not as free.
Still analog. Digital gets snagged by the new filters anyway.
Tried flying last weekend. Too much signal noise—blackout aftermath?
Lots of people out, not usual flyers.
Saw some strange mesh setups near the old yards.
Feels like everyone's watching since that mural showed up.
Makes you rethink how public anything is.
Been sticking with analog—digital channel logs too much.
The blackout messed with a lot of our usual flying spots.
People are out near the mural, not all flying for fun.
Last session, I had to dodge patrol sweeps and pop-up checkpoints.
Signal interference is everywhere now. Way worse than before.
Feels more tense even in old haunts.
Still clears my head, but less relaxing lately.
Mostly analog, but sometimes hybrid to get through dirty bands if I have to.
Since the mural, more people are setting up mesh relays—half activists, half watchers.
Got flagged last run by a drone sweep almost got my score tagged.
Blackout made everyone nervous: new patrol routes, surprise checkpoints.
Had to clip my battery early just to avoid a cluster near the freight yard.
Honestly, one bad decision and it’s not just your drone that gets ghosted.
I still fly. Just have to think three moves ahead now.
Can’t risk getting pegged as a signal anomaly.
Analog, for sure. Digital’s too easy for the system to map to profiles now.
I used to fly just to escape, but now it’s part scouting, part stress test.
After the blackout, I saw people using drone footage to map out patrol gaps.
Some set up encrypted mesh nets—it’s coordinated, not random.
Last week I picked up Directorate encryption bursts mid-flight—couldn’t risk getting closer.
My BCI score tanked right after, still haven’t bounced back.
Whole scene’s changed: fewer casual pilots, more eyes, more risks.
Sometimes I miss when the only worry was breaking a prop.
But seeing how fast people adapt—think it says something about why all this tech was built.
